docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: The nuclear-reactor accident at Chernobyl a year ago spewed radiation into the atmosphere for only a few days before it was choked off, but the effects on human health will continue to unfold well into the next century.

headline.main: CHERNOBYL'S LEGACY: DAYS OF RADIATION, BUT DECADES OF FEARS OVER HEALTH

byline.original: By HAROLD M. SCHMECK Jr., Special to the New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: DR. PAUL A. MARKS IS confident the time is at hand. ''We're ready for the next quantum jump in terms of being effective against cancer,'' he says, his piercing blue eyes staring out through aviator glasses, their very intensity seeming to will the quantum jump to proceed. Marks is president and chief executive officer of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, the nation's oldest and largest research and hospital complex devoted exclusively to cancer.
